Environmental Issue/Concern:
New Pipeline in Alberta
Trench subsidence
Location: 2010 - Approx. 90 sites in 110 km section between; Section 2-31-4-W4 and Section 34-22-4-W4.  2011 – In addition to areas noted above, all land  tracts were assessed in 2011
Current Status 2010: The total area within the 110 km section is approx. 1.8 ha.  Typical areas are 20m in length, 2-3 m wide and < 0.3m deep.
Current Status 2011: •  Numerous site deficiencies were corrected by stripping back topsoil and feathering in subsoil, or if very small or possibly in pasture/ native range, acceptable topsoil sources are secured and used to fill-in trench subsidence.  •  Sites were assessed with remediation completed on areas with potential to impact landowner and/ or pipeline operations.
Recommendation/Schedule: Spring thru Fall 2012.  Balance of known sites, along with new observations from 2011 will  continue to be monitored in 2012, with remediation to be completed based on  discussions with landowners

Environmental Issue/Concern: Underground spring surfaced creating soft ground conditions around pipeline trench
Current Status 2010:
Monitored in 2010
Also discussed during NEB Post-Construction Monitoring inspection in September 2010.
Current Status 2011: •  Monitored in 2011.  Soft ground conditions did not correct naturally, potentially creating land-use (grazing) and pipeline operation issues. •  Implemented plan that included installation of gravel and weeping tile to divert flow away from the pipeline trench and onto stable, vegetated ground.

Environmental Issue/Concern:
New Pipeline in Manitoba
Trench subsidence and overall drainage around station
Location: NE 13-9-5-WP Adjacent to Elm Creek Pigging Station
Current Status 2010: Unable to complete work in 2010 due to very wet conditions
Current Status 2011: •  Land-levelling completed around the ECPS in 2011. •  Ditch subsidence corrected/filled with land-levelling.
Recommendation/Schedule: No significant rain events since levelling completed to assess effectiveness. Requires monitoring in 2012.

Environmental Issue/Concern:
New Pipeline in Manitoba
Berm along drainage ditch adjacent to road
Current Status 2010: Work completed in July 2010 as part of Post-Construction Monitoring
Current Status 2011: •  Monitored in 2011- heavy spring runoff and summer rainfall, berm integrity maintained.  Additional material was added to top of berm in 2011 during land-levelling of adjacent farm field.

Environmental Issue/Concern:
New pipeline in Manitoba
Drainage adjacent to MLV Carman 49+200
Current Status 2010: Work completed in November 2010 as part of Post-Construction Monitoring
Current Status 2011: •  Due to landowner crop loss claim in regard to ineffective drainage around compound, additional land-levelling completed Fall 2011. •  Fine-tuned drainage around compound.

Environmental Issue/Concern:
New pipeline in Manitoba
Potential land levelling
Location: Areas on numerous tracts.  Sizes ranging from 5 m length to 200 m length, and 5 m wide to full width of right-of-way.
Current Status 2010: 2010 helicopter reconnaissance with  video capability, some ground recon, as well as discussions with landowners noted inconsistencies in contours across the right-of-way. Land levelling completed in a few locations in 2010.
Current Status 2011: •  Land-levelling completed on various land-tracts in 2011. •  2011 assessments determined uneven field surface contours (high spots/low spots).  •  Normal farm practices do not readily correct these inconsistencies.
Recommendation/Schedule: Keystone to consult further with affected landowners in 2012 to address inconsistencies in contours/ drainage across the right-of-way. Land-levelling required in 2012.

Environmental Issue/Concern: New Pipeline in Alberta Native Vegetation establishment
Current Status 2010: 2010 Post-Construction Monitoring indicates acceptable re-growth
Current Status 2011: •  2011 Post-Construction Monitoring indicates acceptable re-growth
Recommendation/Schedule: Continue to monitor in 2012 to determine if additional remediation (re-seed) is required.

Environmental Issue/Concern: New Pipeline in Alberta  Native Vegetation establishment
Current Status 2010: 2010 PCRM indicates very good native species germination and ground cover. Other than deficiency as noted in September 8, 2010 record, ground is fully stabilized.
Current Status 2011: •  2011 PCRM indicates very good native species germination and ground cover. Ground is fully stabilized.   •  Deficiency as noted in September 8, 2010 record, indicates good native species germination and ground cover.
Recommendation/Schedule: Continue to monitor in 2012 to assess germination in areas noted as being deficient in September 2010, and assess re-vegetation success.

Environmental Issue/Concern: New Pipeline in Alberta Bank contouring
Current Status 2010: Banks are stable in 2010, some minor slumping to be further assessed to determine if re-work and stabilizing bank is warranted
Current Status 2011: •  Banks remain stable in 2011.  •  Repair of minor slumping does not appear to be warranted at this time.

Environmental Issue/Concern: New Pipeline in Alberta  Shrub Planting
Current Status 2010: Work not completed in 2010.
Current Status 2011: •  Planted approximately 170 Manitoba Maple and Chokecherry on banks, completed in June 2011.

Location: Hardisty Tank Terminal  PS 5 – Hardisty  NW-29-42-9-W4
Current Status 2010: Pre-construction design drawings included provisions for site drainage controls.  During construction, drainage controls were evaluated and some modified but preserve the integrity of the original drainage design for the site.      When conditions permit in Spring 2011, a civil design assessment will be conducted to assess current drainage maintenance and correct, if required.
Current Status 2011: •  All site drainage deficiencies were corrected in 2010 reassessed in 2011 during spring melt and some additional corrections were implemented, all deficiencies are considered completed.

Current Status 2010: Perimeter slope grading and stabilization was conducted with the exception of a portion in the northeast corner of the site due to the planned installation of a second Static VAR Compensator. Complete re-grading of perimeter slope and stabilization when conditions permit in Spring 2011. Complete storm water drainage swale when conditions permit in Spring 2011.  Strip granular, re-construct swale and replace granular.
Current Status 2011: •  Re-grading and stabilization completed in 2011 •  Site Storm water drainage completed in 2011

Current Status 2010: Scope of work complete.
Current Status 2011: •  No issues, No work required

Current Status 2010: Year one post-construction monitoring indicates lack of growth and the presence of some undesirable vegetation on the permanent topsoil stockpile and the reclaimed area south of the E-house/ substation. Seeding of the topsoil stockpile and area south of the E-house/substation to be completed in the Spring of 2011, subject to weather conditions.
Current Status 2011: •  Vegetation on topsoil stockpile and grassy area south of the E house is excellent with little/no weeds •  Minor drainage/ erosion issue within the station completed in Fall 2011

Current Status 2010: A planned clean storm water drainage ditch along east limit of site was not constructed due to the presence of a slurry pit temporarily located in the area for the planned ditch.  When conditions permit in Spring 2011, the slurry pit will be reclaimed and the surface drainage ditch will be constructed along the east side of the site.
Current Status 2011: •  Slurry pit reclaimed •  Site Drainage assessed, design corrections made, constructed and completed

Current Status 2010: Due to extreme wet conditions throughout 2010, there were delays in some construction activities including the following: Containment swale liner not secured into the top of bank; Laydown area south of pump station has not been fully reclaimed; Pond overflow elevation needs to be confirmed.   Liner to be excavated and re-secured when conditions permit in the Spring of 2011. Reclaim laydown area south of pump station.  Cleanup, replace topsoil and re-seed when conditions permit in the Spring of 2011. When conditions permit in Spring 2011, assess elevations and undertake necessary work to ensure overflow is at correct elevation.
Current Status 2011: •  Site Drainage berms reconstructed and completed •  Liner secured •  Laydown area reclaimed and seeded

Current Status 2010: Due to extreme wet conditions throughout 2010, some activities including the following, were not completed: Install culvert along access road; Site drainage to be assessed in Spring 2011; Containment swale extends beyond fenceline and drain control valve is also located outside the present fenceline; Unable to install rip rap and geotech at culvert outlet of the containment swale. All work complete.

Current Status 2010: Spots backfilled over line on new RoW has settled in some spots and water is pooling, topsoil may be require to be brought in to fill these spots, or re grading. Land owners drainage ditch was not contoured back to grade and water is not running through it but pooling in it instead.  Re-contour soil on new RoW, topsoil may be required to be brought in to fill these spots. Re-contour drainage ditch to allow water to move without pooling. - Spring thru Fall 2011
Current Status 2011: Field was not land levelled in 2011 due to lack of specialized equipment availability.
Recommendation/Schedule: Land-levelling planned for 2012.   Topsoil import should not be required-land-levelling will correct ditch subsidence and restore drain and field contours.

Current Status 2010: Minor soils mixing during the topsoil stripping and site access components. Site cleanup in 2010 uniformly replaced topsoil across affected portions of the right-of-way. As additional cleanup to correct deficiencies was completed as various times in the growing season, seeding of crops and associated productivity could not be quantified.  Although early indications show no further concerns, assessments will be conducted at the appropriate time in 2011 to determine if additional remediation is required
Current Status 2011: Sites assessed prior to seeding, during growing season, before harvest and after harvest. Crop production same as off right-of-way in majority of site, with small locations of slightly more sparse crops. Subsidence observed in 2011 assessments, with most completed.
Recommendation/Schedule: Complete subsidence repairs in 2012. Continue monitoring crop production in affected areas in 2012
